thread.title: Funktoberfest crowd braves rain for beer
thread.title_full: Funktoberfest crowd braves rain for beer

title: Funktoberfest crowd braves rain for beer
text:
Funktoberfest crowd braves rain for beer Leigh Guidry , lguidry@thetowntalk.com, (318) 487-6445 7:01 p.m. CDT October 24, 2015 Buy Photo Justin Bailey and Edan Moran serve their home brews from a shared tent Saturday at Funktoberfest at Spirits Food & Friends in Alexandria. (Photo: Leigh Guidry/The Town Talk) Buy Photo 5 CONNECT 5 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Rain couldn't keep home-brewers or their ready taste-testers from the first Funktoberfest Craft Brew and Music Festival on Saturday in Alexandria. 
Spirits Food & Friends organized and hosted the event that featured live music on a large stage next to the restaurant and several tents serving samples of beer. Local craft brewers competed as part of the Oktoberfest-like celebration. 
Lesley Moran and several friends supported her husband's beer, sporting his Thirty 2 Ten logo on their shirts. 
"I'm here to support everyone and enjoy the craft of homebrewing," Lesley said. 
Dr. Edan Moran, of Alexandria, has been brewing about five years, his wife said. 
"It was the first time there was (a craft brew contest) in this area, and he was excited to try it out," she said. 
Moran served his "Red My Mind Ale" from a tent he shared with another competitor, Justin Bailey of Pineville. Funktoberfest organizers brewing up a good time 
The festival attracted 10 home brewers from as far as Texas and sold more than 500 tickets, said Spirits owner Lee Gwinn. The public "voted with their dollars" in the brewing contest for the “People’s Choice” award. All the “votes” will benefit the local Tipitina’s Foundation Instruments A Comin’ program, which donates instruments to local schools. The brewers also judged each other for the “Top Brewer” award. 
Moran won People's Choice, and Jim Cox of Lafayette won Brewer's Choice, Gwinn said. Buy Photo 
Jocelyn Jones, Nicholas Mabrey and Ann Lowrey, all of Alexandria, dance in the rain Saturday during Funktoberfest at Spirits Food & Friends in Alexandria. (Photo: Leigh Guidry/The Town Talk) 
Although they couldn't compete, other craft brewing companies were invited to participate in Funktoberfest. Jonathan Knoll, owner of Broken Wheel Brewery in Marksville, said it was a no-brainer to help sponsor the event and join the festivities. 
"We're the first craft brewery in Central Louisiana. This is the first craft brew festival in Central Louisiana. It was a natural fit," Knoll said. 
Most attendants kept to the tents, but were not afraid to step out for more beer. 
"So far it's been awesome," Marcus Brown, of Alexandria, said. "I'm trying as much as I can. ... You've still got to get wet to get beer." 
Was it worth the short walk in the rain? 
"I think so," he said. 
Brown was excited to have something new to do in town, especially on a weekend when he has a babysitter. 
"It's nice to not have to drive down the highway," he said. 
Others gave up on the tents and embraced the rain, getting close to the stage to sway to the music in their ponchos. 
Net proceeds from Funktoberfest — after the musical acts and other expenses are paid — will benefit Tipitina’s. 5 CONNECT 5 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://www.thetowntalk.com/story/news/2015/10/24/funktoberfest-crowd-braves-rain-beer/74229562/ TOP VIDEOS
